name: Polynomials & Factorization
description: Breaking down polynomials into simpler factors to reveal structure and solutions.

cards.title: Common Factoring Methods
cards.description: Understanding basic factoring techniques to simplify polynomials.
bulletpoints: Factor out the greatest common factor (GCF): \[ ax^n + bx^{n-1} = x^{n-1} (ax + b) \].
Recognize special binomial patterns: \[ a^2 - b^2 = (a - b)(a + b) \] (difference of squares).
Factor sum and difference of cubes: \[ a^3 - b^3 = (a - b)(a^2 + ab + b^2) \], \[ a^3 + b^3 = (a + b)(a^2 - ab + b^2) \].
Use grouping methods for higher-degree polynomials, such as factoring four-term polynomials.

cards.title: Polynomial Division & Synthetic Division
cards.description: Techniques for dividing polynomials and finding roots efficiently.
bulletpoints: Use long division to divide polynomials: \[ \frac{x^3 + 2x^2 - 4x - 8}{x - 2} \].
Apply synthetic division for division by linear factors \( x - c \). Example:
\[ \begin{array}{r|rrrr} 2 & 1 & 2 & -4 & -8 \\ \hline & 1 & 4 & 4 & 0 \end{array} \].
Use the remainder theorem: If \( f(c) = 0 \), then \( x - c \) is a factor of \( f(x) \).
Apply the factor theorem to identify divisors: If \( f(x) \) has a factor \( (x - c) \), then \( f(c) = 0 \).

cards.title: Finding Roots & Graphing Polynomials
cards.description: Understanding how to locate the zeros of polynomial functions and analyze their graphs.
bulletpoints: Find polynomial roots by factoring completely: \[ (x - 2)(x + 3) = 0 \Rightarrow x = 2, -3 \].

Apply the Rational Root Theorem: Possible rational roots of \( ax^n + bx^{n-1} + ... + c \) are \( \pm \frac{p}{q} \), where \( p \) and \( q \) are factors of the constant term and leading coefficient.
Analyze end behavior using the degree and leading coefficient:
- If \( n \) is even and \( a_n > 0 \), both ends point up.
- If \( n \) is even and \( a_n < 0 \), both ends point down.
- If \( n \) is odd and \( a_n > 0 \), the function rises to the right and falls to the left.
- If \( n \) is odd and \( a_n < 0 \), the function falls to the right and rises to the left.

cards.title: Factoring Quadratic Polynomials
cards.description: Breaking down second-degree polynomials into factors.
bulletpoints: Factor trinomials of the form \( ax^2 + bx + c \) using trial and error or AC method.
Recognize perfect square trinomials: \[ a^2 + 2ab + b^2 = (a + b)^2 \].
Solve quadratic equations using factoring: \[ x^2 - 5x + 6 = 0 \Rightarrow (x - 2)(x - 3) = 0 \Rightarrow x = 2, 3 \].

cards.title: Irreducible Polynomials & Prime Factorization
cards.description: Identifying polynomials that cannot be factored further over a given number system.
bulletpoints: A polynomial is irreducible over the real numbers if it cannot be factored into two lower-degree real polynomials.
Example: \( x^2 + 1 \) is irreducible over \( \mathbb{R} \) but factorable over \( \mathbb{C} \): \[ x^2 + 1 = (x - i)(x + i) \].
Identify prime polynomials which cannot be factored further in a given field.

cards.title: Polynomial Identities & Special Products
cards.description: Recognizing and using algebraic identities for rapid factorization.
bulletpoints: Sum and difference of cubes:
Recognize the difference of squares: \[ a^2 - b^2 = (a - b)(a + b) \].
Recognize the trinomial square patterns: \[ a^2 + 2ab + b^2 = (a + b)^2 \].

cards.title: Binomial Theorem & Expansion
cards.description: Using binomial expansion to express polynomials raised to powers.
bulletpoints: The Binomial Theorem states:
\[ (a + b)^n = \sum_{k=0}^{n} \binom{n}{k} a^{n-k} b^k \].
Example: Expand \( (x + 2)^3 \):
Each coefficient is given by the binomial coefficient: \[ \binom{n}{k} = \frac{n!}{k!(n-k)!} \].
